DATATYPE.Description: A very small integer. The signed range is -128 to 127. The unsigned range is 0 to 255.
A small integer. The signed range is -32768 to 32767. The unsigned range is 0 to 65535.
A medium-size integer. The signed range is -8388608 to 8388607. The unsigned range is 0 to 16777215.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A large integer. The signed range is -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807. The unsigned range is 0 to 18446744073709551615.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.

A normal-size (double-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -1.7976931348623157E+308 to -2.2250738585072014E-308, 0, and 2.2250738585072014E-308 to 1.7976931348623157E+308.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
An unpacked floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Behaves like a CHAR column.
This is a synonym for DECIMAL.
A date. The supported range is \a1000-01-01\a to \a9999-12-31\a.
A date and time combination. The supported range is \a1000-01-01 00:00:00\a to \a9999-12-31 23:59:59\a.
A timestamp. The range is \a1970-01-01 00:00:00\a to sometime in the year 2037. The length can be 14 (or missing), 12, 10, 8, 6, 4, or 2 representing YYYYMMDDHHMMSS, ... , YYYYMMDD, ... , YY formats.
A time. The range is \a-838:59:59\a to \a838:59:59\a.
A year in 2- or 4-digit format (default is 4-digit).

A fixed-length string (1 to 255 characters) that is always right-padded with spaces to the specified length when stored. values are sorted and compared in case-insensitive fashion according to the default character set unless the BINARY keyword is given.
A variable-length string (1 to 255 characters). Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion unless the BINARY keyword is given.
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters.
An enumeration. A string object that can have only one value, chosen from the list of values.
A set. A string object that can have zero or more values, each of which must be chosen from the list of values.
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype

TABLE.StandardInserts: INSERT INTO stSoftwareVersions(software, version, date, description) VALUES \n (\aPako\a,\a1.0.6.3\a,\a2007-02-22\a ,\aSoftware for setting/running the observations at the IRAM-30m\a);\n
TABLE.Comments: Static table with the different software versions.

Please notice this is not a Source Catalog!\nOne scan integrates on a source, so a row with the source is store for each scan. Should be the same sources as specified in the PredefinedSources, but we don\at have any constraints about it (observer freedom)
Table with all the Astronomers known. Special atention to sync with Clemens database, and with name convention (WikiName?) Under discussion.
In the predefinedComment, should be needed a \Adefault\A predefined comment, like a \Anull\A comment.

COLUMN.Comments: True when it\as a technical predefined comment

TABLE.Comments: p2 \+ p7: observer input pointing corrections\np4 \+ p5: inclinometers

Static table with all the Observing Modes:
calibrate
pointing
focus
tip
onOff
onTheFlyMap
track
VLBI

TABLE.StandardInserts:
INSERT INTO stSwitchingModes(name,description) VALUES 
(\atotalPower\a, \aRefers simply to data acquisition without any of the other 3 fast Switching Modes. Normally, when using Total Power one or several positions \AON\A the source are observed alternating with one or several \AOFF\A-source reference positions, and the signal is calculated as the difference between \AON\A and \AOFF\A.\a),
(\abeamSwitching\a,\aIs done through a rotating chopper wheel in the receiver cabin, which during each rotation (= switching cycle) moves 2 reflecting blades into the beam path in front of the 4th mirror. The offset, rotation period, and blanking times are fixed.Beam Switching is normally only used for POINTING and FOCUS. The source signal is calculated as difference between the direct and offset phases.\a),
(\awobblerSwitching\a, \aDuring this switching mode, the wobbling secondary mirror is switched between 2 positions, which are offset from the telescope axis by \194\177 a fixed amount. Wobbler Switching is normally used with ONOFF or, for bolometer continuum mapping, with OTFMAP.\a),
(\afrequencySwitching\a,\aSwitches between 2 different frequencies, so that there are 2 phases. The (source) signal is calculated as the difference between these 2 phases. Frequency Switching is normally used with TRACK or OTFMAP.\a);
TABLE.Comments:
Static table with all the Switching Modes:
totalPower
beamSwitching
wobblerSwitching
frequencySwitching
Static table with the pointing model when updated. Read them from Elvin!

Static table with the available file locations. In the \Apath\A varchar, tags could be used, e.g. \A/vis/{PRJ_ID}/observationData/{YYYYMM}\A\n\nNotice this table is not related with Scan. Scan will kept the filename attribute and the path to this file will be build on the fly using FileLocations table and the IP of the user.

TABLE.StandardInserts:
INSERT INTO stRxNames(name, description) VALUES 
 (\aA100\a,\a3mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 80 and 115.5 GHz.\a), 
 (\aA230\a,\a1mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 197 and 266 GHz.\a), 
 (\aB100\a,\a3mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 81 and 115.5 GHz.\a), 
 (\aB230\a,\a1mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 197 and 266 GHz.\a), 
 (\aC150\a,\a2mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 130 and 183 GHz.\a), 
 (\aC270\a,\a1mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 241 and 281 GHz.\a), 
 (\aD150\a,\a2mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 130 and 183 GHz.\a), 
 (\aD270\a,\a1mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 241 and 281 GHz.\a), 
 (\aMAMBO1\a,\a37 bolometer array at 1mm from the MPIfR.\a), 
 (\aMAMBO2\a,\a117 bolometer array at 1mm from the MPIfR.\a), 
 (\aHERA1pix1\a,\aPixel 1 of the HEterodyne Receivers Array (HERA). Vertical component, tunable between 215 and 241 GHz.\a), 
 (\aHERA1pix2\a,\aPixel 2 of the HEterodyne Receivers Array (HERA). Vertical component, tunable between 215 and 241 GHz.\a), 
(\aHERA1pix3\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA1pix4\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA1pix5\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA1pix6\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA1pix7\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA1pix8\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA1pix9\a,\a \a), 
 (\aHERA2pix1\a,\aPixel 1 of the HEterodyne Receivers Array (HERA). Horizontal component, tunable between 215 and 272 GHz.\a), 
 (\aHERA2pix2\a,\aPixel 2 of the HEterodyne Receivers Array (HERA). Horizontal component, tunable between 215 and 272 GHz.\a), 
(\aHERA2pix3\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA2pix4\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA2pix5\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA2pix6\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA2pix7\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA2pix8\a,\a \a), 
(\aHERA2pix9\a,\a \a);

INSERT INTO stBkNames(name,description) VALUES
(\aContinuum\a, \aContinuum backend 1 channel per receiver.\a),
(\a4MHz\a, \aPhysically, there are a total of 9 4MHz filterbanks, each with a fixed resolution of 4MHz and bandwidth of 1024 MHz.\a),
(\a1MHz\a, \aThe 1MHz filterbank can be used with 1, 2, 3, or 4 parts with 256, 512, 768, or 1024 MHz bandwidth; but the total number of 1MHz channels is limited to 1024.\a),
(\a100kHz\a, \aThe 100kHz filterbank can be used in one part with 25.3 MHz bandwidth, or in 2 parts each with 12.8 MHz bandwidth.\a),
(\aWILMA\a, \aWILMA has a fixed resolution of 2 MHz and bandwidth of 1024 MHz (theoretical), of which about 930 MHz are practically usable. 2 WILMA parts (times 9) can be connected to HERA1 and/or HERA2.\a),
(\aVESPA\a, \aVESPA allows many different resolutions and bandwidths, depending the \Amode\A used. For details see the VESPA user\\226\128\153s guide.\a),
(\aABBA\a,\aBackend ABBA (Adc Bolometer BAckend) for the Mambo and Mambo2 photometers data acquisition from the Max-Planck-Institut fur Radioastronomie.\a);

INSERT INTO stSystemNames(name, description) VALUES 
 (\aprojection\a,\aThe standard simple \Aradio\A projection offsets in the chosen coordinate system. This is normally the astronomical system of offsets in which point-by-point (TRACK, ONOFF) or on-the-fly (OTFMAP) maps are made.\a), 
 (\ahorizontalTrue\a,\aThe horizontal system with a factor 1/cos(elevation) applied to the azimuth offset. This is the system in which OTF maps with Wobbler switching and the bolometer are normally done.\a), 
 (\anasmyth\a,\aSystem with the special offsets in the Nasmyth reference to point an off-center pixel of a focal-plane array receiver (bolometer, HERA) to the commanded astronomical position, e.g., to use an off-center pixel for pointing, focus, ONOFF.\a);

COLUMN.Comments: Si es null es que doGainImage=FALSE

TABLE.Comments: General offsets specified in the \kRESOURCE name=\Aoffsets\A\g, in PaKo XML
This is a source catalog for the Project. It is based on the sources specified on the project proposal.\n\nNOTE: aimedRMS \+ actualRMS are in mJy in the Pool DB -\g Jy

TABLE.StandardInserts:
INSERT INTO Pools(name, description) VALUES 
 (\aBoloS07\a,\aBolometer (Mambo2) pool for the summer period 2007\a), 
 (\aHeraS07\a,\aHera pool for the summer period 2007\a), 
 (\aBoloW0708\a,\aBolometer (Mambo2) pool for the winter period 2007-2008\a);

TABLE.StandardInserts:
INSERT INTO stTelescopeStates(name, description) VALUES 
 (\aHera\a,\aObserving with the Hera receiver.\a), 
 (\aBolometer\a,\aObserving with bolometer.\a), 
 (\aHeterodyne\a,\aObserving with the heterodyne receivers.\a), 
 (\aTechnical Problem\a,\aTelescope stopped due to a technical problem.\a), 
 (\aBad weather\a,\aTelescope stopped due to bad weather.\a), 
 (\aMaintenance\a,\aMaintenance of the IRAM-30m.\a);
TABLE.Comments:
The telescope states could be (initially):
-Hera
-Bolometer
-Heterodyne
-Technical Problem
-Bad weather
-Maintenance

TABLE.StandardInserts:
INSERT INTO stProjectModes(name, description) VALUES 
 (\aBoloMap\a,\aOTF maps with the bolometer for the project.\a), 
 (\aBoloOnOff\a,\aOn-Off integration on a point source with the bolometer for the project.\a), 
 (\aSIS\a,\aIntegration with heterodyne receivers for the project.\a), 
 (\aHERA\a,\aIntegration with the HERA receiver for the project.\a);

RELATION.RelationName: Sw versions used in the scan
Sw versions used in the scan
A receiver is filtered by many backends band
An ObsComment has only one predefinedComment
One user (astronomer) is the P.I. of the project
A pointing model is used for a lot of scans
A scan has an Observing Mode assigned
Receivers could have a freq. switching applied
General offsets applied to the scan
Receiver used for the Gain Image (only Het)
Sources predefined in the project proposal
Project is in a pool or various pools
List of receivers predefined in the project proposal
List of basebands of the backend
Project could be various mode (e.g. Bolo \+ SIS)

NOTE.NoteText:
Please notice this 
is not a Source Catalog!
A row per source integrated
on each scan is stored.

In principle, this sources 
should be the same as 
specified in the 
PredefinedSources, but 
actually that\as up to 
the observer so there 
are no constraints on this.

\A/vis/{PRJ_ID}/observationData/{YYYYMM}\A

Notice this table is not related with
Scan. Scan will kept the filename
attribute and the path to this file will
be build on the fly using
